conclusion: The particle starts from rest, and its position x(t) is obtained by two consecutive integrations of the given acceleration-versus-time graph.
First integrate a(t) to get v(t).
From t = 0 to t = t0 the acceleration is everywhere positive.
The velocity rises from 0 to a positive maximum at t = t0.
From t = t0 to t = 2t0 the acceleration is negative.
The time-integral of the negative acceleration is just large enough to reduce the velocity smoothly back to 0 at t = 2t0.
The area under the negative part of the a-curve exactly cancels the area under the positive part.
The velocity is positive for all times 0 < t < 2t0 and vanishes only at t = 0 and t = 2t0.
Because v(t) stays positive on the whole open interval (0, 2t0), the displacement s(t) = ∫0^t v(τ) dτ increases monotonically from t = 0 up to t = 2t0.
After t = 2t0, the particle would reverse (v would become negative), but up to 2t0 it never moves back toward the origin.
The greatest distance from the starting point is reached precisely when the velocity first returns to zero.
